I had been operated by Dr. Prabhat Lakkireddi on Aug 16 2018 for an Arthroscopic Bankart repair surgery on my right shoulder, which is a minimally invasive surgery to repair instability and restore function of a dislocated shoulder. I live in the United States and the injury first occurred while playing volleyball and later dislocated on several occasions while swimming, basketball, cricket etc. totaling to about 6 painful dislocations. This is common in Athletes wherein a few tend to put the shoulder back into position without pain, but for me, I am well built at 6ft/ 85kgs and when the shoulder dislocates the whole body is like locked and the only position of the body is to kneel and lay my arm on the ground. The body in an uncomfortable position and the pain is immense.

On my visit to India, I've searched the web and found Dr. Lakkireddi on Practo. He was my first choice but was hesitant to visit him because of where he practiced. (Don't ask me why). I had seen a couple of Doctors before I visited Dr Lakkireddi but finally opted purely based off the reviews on Practo and this time followed my gut and gave it a shot. I was very impressed on the first visit for the reason, he speaks to you as someone you've know for a while and him just being more than a Doctor. Most Doctors explain the issue and the treatment needed which to me is common, but its the confidence that Doctor creates in the patient who needs to get treated moreover a surgery. I've been in pain for more than 2yrs and did not want to go under the knife for the wrong reasons. 

I had planned for a surgery earlier at another hospital, had my MRI reports/ blood work done but backed off due to bad experience just 1 hour before the surgery. Dr. Lakkireddi used the same reports and blood work to diagnose and I decided to go for the surgery without a second thought. It all happened in 10-15min and that's the confidence he created in me as a Doctor that you don't see anymore or rarely. 

I am proud that I made my decision and thanks to Dr. Lakkireddi and his office assistant Venkat, Dr Shekar Reddy (Anesthesia) and his other team members (Sorry I don't recall the names) for helping me out. The surgery was a bit complex than expected as I might have damaged due to multiple dislocations. Its been 4 months that I had the surgery and I am recovering well. I had done a lot of research online on the Bankart Repair before the surgery and being sports person and its easy for me to do a rehab and adopt to physiotherapy. I've visited Dr Lakkireddi a couple of times after the surgery but never got a chance to interact on the Physiotherapy as I had to leave back to the U.S. I am working on my own and have a full movement but will go for muscle strengthening over the next few months and I shall see Dr. Lakkireddi on my next visit to India.

Thank you to know that you had a
HAPPY KNEE. In the view of negative feedback given by one of my patients parent two months back, I wish to discuss about MONEY AND ETHICS IN MEDICAL PRACTICE. And DETERIORATING OPINION ON DOCTORS.
I see an average 30-40patients a day which around 6000/year. If 8 out of 6000 give me a negative feedback, I don’t worry as mostly are about delays in clinic which are beyond my control during an emergency case. But even if one patient comments about about my MEDICAL ETHICS, that hurts me and make me look into my inner conscious and question myself “am I the unethical person the lady is taking about.” 
I will give an example of how PATIENTS INTERPRET DECISION MAKING.
I saw a 12year old child with knee dislocation. Scan shows ligament tear which needs surgery. If you go for a second opinion, there is very fair chance the doctor won’t agree with surgical decision as we know that most patients coming second opinion don’t want surgery at that point. Does this mean that first date is unethical ? Of course I see on a daily basis where surgery was wrongly suggested when there is absolutely no indication. 
KNEE LIGAMENT INJURIES NEED SURGERY NOT TO IMPROVE PAIN, but to prevent any instability in future which when untreated leads to arthritis in joint over 5years. So if you treat a ACL TEAR  patient without surgery, he will walk again in properly in few weeks. That doesn’t mean surgery is not required at all.  Most  people slowly damage the joint because of knee jerking with every step and worse with running or playing sports. How do I make patient understand the long term issues. 
I operate some knee ligament injuries immediately after injury and some even 4-5 years after the ligament tear. The difference between those two cases  is the damage done to joint in patients who have delayed surgery. 
So QUESTIONING ETHICALITY OF A GOOD DOCTOR IS WRONG.  We study close to 30years to understand the intricacies in decision making. How can a person judge a doctor  based on information gathered in few minutes from google or from another doctor ? 
Please question yourself, before posting demoralising statements.
